msDesc.head: A Einhard, Notker Balbulus; Germany (Eberbach?), 12th century, last quarter; B Sermons and treatises on dictamen; German, 13th century, first half or middle

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard for Abp. Laud, 1637–1639.

history.provenance: Eberbach, Cistercian abbey: parts 1 and 2 together identifiable as g27 in the 1502 library catalogue.
history.acquisition: Part of his third donation to the Bodleian, 1639.

recordHist.source:
Description adapted by Tuija Ainonen and Matthew Holford (November 2019) from the following sources (with additional description of the contents): Nigel F. Palmer, Zisterzienser und ihre Bücher: die mittelalterliche Bibliotheksgeschichte von Kloster Eberbach im Rheingau (Regensburg, 1998), pp. 217–220, 274, 296 [physical description, date, origin, provenance] Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, 3 vols. (1966–1973) Addenda, p. 54. H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885 [contents, acquisition]
Quarto Catalogue, cols. 407–8 Quarto Catalogue, p. 571 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 36

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

msItem.author: Einhard
msItem.title: Vita Caroli regis
msItem.incipit: Gens Merowingorum de qua franci reges sibi creare soliti erant

msItem.author: Notker Balbulus
msItem.title: Gesta Karoli Magna
msItem.incipit: Omnipotens rerum dispositor ordinatorque
msItem.explicit: Officium quidem tuum te habere permittimus.

msItem.note: Five lines titled 'De monacho dormiente in choro'. (WIC 6602; Ed. Palmer, p. 218).

msItem.incipit: Deus qui per ingressum angelicum et
msItem.note: Added in the last third of the 13th century to an originally blank verso.

msItem.title: Hymn to the Virgin
msItem.incipit: Ave, stella matutina, peccatorum medicina
msItem.note: Added in the last third of the 13th century to an originally blank verso.

decoDesc.decoNote: Added drawings, fols. 11r (repudiation of Charlemagne's wife), 132v (the Virgin Mary).
Red initials with very sparse decoration

msItem.title: Sermons (?)
msItem.note: Unidentified. Listed in the Eberbach library catalogue as 'sermones quidem'; first on Cant. 4.15, then on Christ's nativity and infancy.

msItem.incipit: Ortus conclusus soror mea sponsa Ortus con Salomon loquitur sed a sapiente quomodo eadem soror que sponsa nuncupatur. Illegitima est harum coniunctio personarum.
msItem.explicit: ab unigenito cordis tui Salvatore nostro, cui est honor et gloria per omnia secula seculorum Amen.

msItem.incipit: (fol. 137v) Fons liquidus ac serenus manens iugiter unde manans. Hodie de corde patris aridam nostri cordis irrigaturus egreditur. Hodie manu emissa de supernis sub ueteri iacens onere mundus erigitur.
(fol. 140r) Rursum eadem que adolescentie statui nomina hec interpretando contulimus noue penitentis conversationi conuenire uidebimus
(fol. 142r) Accusanti se anime suosque iugiter plangenti morbos, si non solum peccatorum remissio, sed et omnis gratie promittatur plentitudo
(fol. 144r) Tales delicias et tantam celestie gratie plenitudinem si uel adolescenti suas plangenti miserias
Exercicium ad perfectionem tendentis anime, quale esse oporteat demonstratur cum infertur, Exurgens autem Maria in diebus...
(fol. 147r) Rudibus ad huc et a timore domini inchoantibus salutis iter
(fol. 148v) Post premissa si series historiae consulitur hec sequentur, Cum esset desponsata mater eius
(fol. 150v) Hystoriam operum saluatoris cum non unus tantum sed plures euangeliste tractent
(fol. 153v) Inspecto quis fuerit descriptionis auctor intueri libet etiam de ministro; ipse est de quo scriptura subiungit, Hec descriptio prima facta est a preside syrie cirino
(fol. 157v) Tota diligenter anima per confessionem ne pristinis rursum sordibus inquinetur, misticis consequenter euangelice lectionis sermonibus eruditur. Factum est autem dum essent ...
(fol. 160r) Illustrantur lumine lucentis anime quicumque sanctos in illa perfectionis radios contemplantur. Unde subditur, Et pastores erant in eadem regione uigilantes
(fol. 162r) Pastoribus ut annunciata leticia nati pueri critice perserueret, credulitatis datur iudicium cum infertur
(fol. 163r) Quam rectissime autem hinc quidem gloria, inde uero par annunciatur. Osculum enim hoc danti ad gloriam, ad pacem uero est accipienti.
(fol. 165r) Post gustatam celestis doni suauitatem, nichil dignius quam ut mens in actione perseueret graciarum
(fol. 167v) Vltimus ad perfectionem gradus est qui in eo exprimitur, quod consequenter infertur, Et postquam consummati sunt dies octo
(fol. 169v) Sicut specialis est glorie uite perfectioris item euntibus exempli lumine esse preambulum, ita salutaris est gratie si perfectum pre cunctis te imiteris exemplum
msItem.explicit: (fol. 178v) celestem loquor patriam, te duce, Jhesu bone, pervenitur, Qui cum Deo patre et Spiritu Sancte vivis et gloriaris Deus per omnia secula seculorum Amen.

msItem.title: Aurea gemma Oxoniensis
msItem.rubric: Incipit ecce liber qui dicitur aurea gemma.
msItem.incipit: Librorum sicut Cantica canticorum per excellentiam liber iste dicitur, eo quod maxima utilitas et maior quam in ceteris
msItem.explicit: quasi ex auro et gemma sit compositus et informatus.
msItem.incipit: (fol. 179r) Sociorum assidua pulsatione coactus
msItem.explicit: Supradictis premissis, ad ostendendum que proposuimus, accedamus altius tamen sic incipiamus.
msItem.incipit: (f. 179v) Solet fieri quaestio qua de causa littere fuerunt invente
De epistolarum quoque ideo queritur
Summa dictaminum hec est divisio
Epistola grece nomen est et compositum est
Nunc vero dicendum est ut sunt tres ordiines personatum, ita et tres sunt species epistolarum
Nunc de modis possitionum seu compositionum dicamus
Alexandro episcopo et universali pontifici patri patris
msItem.note: Includes excerpts from Adalbertus Samaritanus, Praecepta dictaminum (fols. 179r-v) and some letters from Henricus Francigena, Aurea gemma (fols. 186v-190r).

Description in Polak, Emil J., Medieval & Renaissance letter treatises & form letters: a census of manuscripts found in part of western Europe, Japan, & the United States of America, Davis medieval texts and studies, vol. 9 (Brill, 1994), pp. 380–81.

msItem.author: Bernardus de Bononia
msItem.title: Summa dictaminum
msItem.incipit: De dictaminum igitur scientia grata rudibus documenta evidenter ministrare desiderantes
(fol. 191r)Diffinicio dictaminis. Dictamen est congrua et apposita litteralis edicio
msItem.explicit: utilem quippe speramus futurum esse, Domino donante.
msItem.note: Description in Polak, Emil J., Medieval & Renaissance letter treatises & form letters: a census of manuscripts found in part of western Europe, Japan, & the United States of America. Davis medieval texts and studies, vol. 9 (Brill, 1994), pp. 380–81.
Letter from Emperor Baldwin of Flanders to Pope Innocent III
msItem.incipit: Balduinus Dei gratia fidelissimus in Christo imperator constantinopolitanus
msItem.explicit: sicut sub domino progressum accepimus et profectum. Acta sunt hec anno incarnationis dominice mº ccº iiiº indictione vii regnante domino nostro Ihesu Christo.

revisionDesc.change: Description revised for Polonsky digitization project to include additional information from printed descriptions.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
